Tested in eclipse 3.1 M6

If a testcase override the getName() method, returning a meaningful name instead
of the method name, the junit runner uses this name when trying to re-run the
test and fails.

Steps to reproduce:
- add the following testcase

public class NamedTest extends junit.framework.TestCase
{
    public void testSomething()
    {
    }
    public String getName()
    {
        return "A meaningful name, useful when the test is included in a suite.";
    }
}


Run the testcase with Run as -> Junit test.
Now the overridden method name is shown in junit hierarchy page: right click on
the method and select "Run": the test runner fails with the following exception:

junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: Method "A meaningful name, useful when the
test is included in a suite." not found
	at junit.framework.Assert.fail(Assert.java:47)
	at junit.framework.TestCase.runTest(TestCase.java:147)
	at junit.framework.TestCase.runBare(TestCase.java:127)
	at junit.framework.TestResult$1.protect(TestResult.java:106)
	at junit.framework.TestResult.runProtected(TestResult.java:124)
	at junit.framework.TestResult.run(TestResult.java:109)
	at junit.framework.TestCase.run(TestCase.java:118)
	at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.runTests(RemoteTestRunner.java:474)
	at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.run(RemoteTestRunner.java:342)
	at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.runner.RemoteTestRunner.main(RemoteTestRunner.java:194)


Expected behaviour: the junit runner should use the real method name when
rerunning tests, and not the name returned by getName()

This is a known issue that unfortunately cannot be fixed without support from
the JUnit framework. The workaround is to not override getName().
